sec.title: American Fire Sprinkler Association (AFSA) Scholarship Program
sec.p: AFSA was organized in 1981 and is a nonprofit, international association that represents open shop fire sprinkler contractors. It represents approximately 750 companies and individuals in the United States and other countries. AFSA promotes the educational advancement of its members, and wants to educate the public about the dangers of fire and encourage the use of automatic fire sprinkler systems. AFSA believes that thousands of lives and billions of dollars could be saved with the installation of fire sprinklers each year. Membership in AFSA is open to contractors, manufacturers, suppliers, and designers. AFSA supports a scholarship contest for high school seniors who are U.S. citizens or legal residents. Home-schooled seniors are welcome to apply. Students should fill out the registration form, read the “Fire Sprinkler Essay” about automatic fire sprinklers, and take the 10-question multiple-choice test (the number of questions answered correctly is the number of times the student will be entered into a drawing for a US$2,000 scholarship). A total of 10 winners will receive a scholarship of US$2,000. The scholarship will be paid directly to the student’s educational institution to be used for tuition and/or books for the fall 2012 semester. Winners will be contacted within 7 business days of the contest ending date and will have 10 days to respond and verify that they meet the scholarship contest eligibility requirements. Winners’ names will be posted on the contest website in May 2012. Entries are due by April 5, 2012. For more information, please visit http://www.afsascholarship.org/hsinformation.html.

boxed-text.title: Grants and Awards
boxed-text.p: The Ester Katz Rosen program of the American Psychological Foundation funds graduate students whose work centers on the psychological understanding of gifted and talented children and adolescents. The program goals focus on the advancement of the understanding of gifted children for the ultimate purpose of enabling and enhancing development of their talents and on encouraging promising graduate students to conduct research in this area. Eligible applicants must have completed their doctoral candidacy, be in good academic standing at an accredited university in the United States or Canada and enrolled in graduate program during the fellowship year, and have a tuition waiver by home institution. The application deadline is March 1, 2012. Up to US$25,000 will be awarded for 1-year graduate fellowships. For more information, visit http://www.apa.org/apf/funding/rosen.aspx

The Qwest Foundation focuses on enriching the lives of children by supporting the improvement of PreK-Grade 12 educational programs. The Foundation considers programs that effectively use technology, promote innovative models, improve the skills and leadership of educators and parents, promote innovative early childhood education programs, and promote diversity awareness and cultural competency. Eligible applicants must be nonprofit organizations. Requests are reviewed online on an ongoing basis. Final notification of funding decisions is made within 6 to 8 weeks following the grant submission. While the Foundation does not have a range for grant amounts, awards for the past several years generally range between US$5,000 and US$10,000. For more information, visit http://www.centurylink.com/Pages/AboutUs/Community/Foundation/

The Kazanjian Economics Foundation maintains a vital interest in the overall efforts to increase economic literacy. The Foundation is interested in elevating the nation’s understanding of the need for economic education and supports programs that focus on new strategies for teaching economics, including online and web-based instruction; projects, policy studies, or programs that encourage measurement of economic understanding; and programs that help disenfranchised youth and/or young adults with children participate in the economic system. Eligible applicants must be nonprofit organizations. Applications are due by September 15, for review in November, or by February 15, for review in May. The average grant is approximately US$22,000; however, grants as small as US$3,500 and as large as US$150,000 have been made. For more information, visit http://www.kazanjian.org/grants

The Institute of Education Sciences, U.S. Department of Education, intends to contribute to the improvement of reading and writing skills for students from kindergarten through Grade 12. The long-term outcome of this program will be an array of tools and strategies (e.g., assessments, instructional approaches) that have been documented to be effective for improving reading and writing. The Institute will be accepting applications to develop writing interventions during 2012. The anticipated deadline for the application is June 23, 2012. The maximum length of the award period for each goal ranges from 2 to 5 years. The size of the award depends on the goal and scope of the project. For more information, visit http://ies.ed.gov/funding/ncer_rfas/readwrite.asp

The Institute of Education Sciences’ Effective Teachers and Effective Teaching research program supports the identification of effective strategies for improving the performance of classroom teachers in ways that increase student learning and school achievement in reading, writing, mathematics, and the sciences for students from kindergarten through Grade 12. The long-term outcomes of the Effective Teachers research program will be an array of programs (e.g., professional development programs), assessments, and strategies (e.g., recruitment and retention policies) that have been demonstrated to be effective for improving and assessing teacher quality in ways that are linked to increases in student achievement. Applicants include nonprofit and for-profit organizations that have the capacity to conduct scientifically valid research. The anticipated deadline is June 23, 2012. The maximum length of the award period ranges from 2 to 5 years. The size of the award depends on the goal and scope of the project. For more information, visit http://ies.ed.gov/funding/ncer_rfas/effective_teachers.asp

The National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) PreK-Grade 8 Preservice provides financial support for action research conducted by preservice teacher(s) in collaboration with university faculty member(s) and a classroom teacher(s) who seek to improve their understanding of mathematics in PreK-Grade 8 classroom(s). The action research should be designed, implemented, and completed with a focus on enhancing the teaching and/or learning of mathematics. Proposals must address the following: rationale for the research project, the expected impact on teaching/learning in the school setting, and anticipated improvements in preservice student learning. Grant funds should be used to support project expenses to plan and carry out the action research. Eligible applicants should be current full individual or e-members of NCTM or those teaching at a school with a current NCTM PreK-Grade 8 school membership. The participating preservice teacher(s) must be in an initial licensure/certification program at the undergraduate level and, at some point during the term of the grant, must be engaged in some form of practicum experience or student teaching. Deadline for submission of the proposal is May 4, 2012. The maximum award is US$3,000. For more information, visit http://www.nctm.org/resources/content.aspx?id=15479

The Scholastic Lexus Environmental Challenge program is designed to educate and empower students to take action to improve the environment. The program encourages middle and high school students to develop and implement environmental programs that positively affect their communities. Middle and high school teams comprising 5 to 10 students and 1 teacher advisor are invited to participate in four initial challenges, each addressing a different environmental element—land, water, air, and climate. Applicants must be students in Grades 6 to 12 and their teachers. The maximum award is US$75,000. The deadline varies. For more information, visit http://www.scholastic.com/lexus

sec.title: SunTrust Off To College Scholarship Sweepstakes
sec.p: SunTrust Banks, Inc., is one of the nation’s leading financial services holding companies and holds assets totaling US$172.2 billion as of June 30, 2011. Through SunTrust Bank, the company provides deposit, credit, trust, and investment services to a broad range of retail, business, and institutional clients. Other services provided include mortgage banking, insurance, brokerage, investment management, equipment leasing, and capital markets services. The company exists to help people and institutions by providing financial services that meet the needs and enhance the lives of clients, communities, employees, and shareholders. SunTrust is offering the Off-to-College Scholarship Sweepstakes where students can win a US$1,000 scholarship made payable to their accredited college or private career school. Scholarships must be used for tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for study. High school seniors planning to attend college or current college students who will be continuing their undergraduate studies in the fall of 2012 are eligible to enter the sweepstakes. There is no application fee, and eligibility is not based on grade point average or financial need. In all, 15 separate drawings will be held and one winner will be chosen every 2 weeks from October 28, 2011, through May 11, 2012. To enter, students should complete an online entry form by accessing the SunTrust Education Loans website page (offtocollege.info). Or, entrants can write their name, date of birth, address, city, state, zip, day and evening phone numbers, and the words, “SunTrust Off To College Scholarship Sweepstakes” on a 3″ × 5″ card, and mail it in a stamped #10 envelope to SunTrust Off To College Scholarship Sweepstakes, P.O. Box 27172, Richmond, VA, 23261-7172. Students may only submit one entry per drawing, but are welcome to register again for each drawing period because entries do not carry over into the next drawing. Winners will be sent a notification letter by U.S. Mail or Federal Express approximately 1 week after each of the 15 drawings. Verification of school registration will be required to claim the scholarship prize. Winners’ names will be posted on the SunTrust Education Loans website. Entries must be received by May 11, 2012, for the final drawing. For more information, please visit http://www.suntrusteducation.com/sweeps/

sec.title: The 16th Annual Signet Classics Student Scholarship Essay Contest
sec.p: Penguin Group (USA) Inc. is the U.S. affiliate of the internationally renowned Penguin Group, one of the largest English-language trade book publishers in the world. Penguin Group (USA) Inc. is also a global leader in children’s publishing and is hosting the 16th annual Signet Classics Student Scholarship Essay Contest for high school juniors and seniors. Essays must be submitted by a high school English teacher on behalf of students who write an essay on one of five topics on, Emma, by Jane Austen. Essays must be between two and three typed, double-spaced pages long. Students should include four copies (including the cover letter) of each essay submitted. The criteria that the judges will use include clear, concise writing that is (a) original, (b) articulate, (c) logically organized, and (d) well supported. Winning essays will demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the themes and issues that are presented in the book. Five US$1,000 prizes will be awarded that are to be used toward the winner’s tuition expenses. Each prize also includes a Signet Classics Library for the winner’s school library, or public library in the case of a home-schooled winner with an approximate retail value of US$1,600. All entries must be postmarked by April 13, 2012. Winners will be notified by June 22, 2012. For more information, please visit http://us.penguingroup.com/static/pages/services-academic/essayhome.html

sec.title: Math Hero Awards Program
sec.p: Raytheon is a technology and innovation firm specializing in defense, homeland security, and other government markets by providing state-of-the-art electronics, communications, and intelligence systems. Raytheon is pleased to offer the MathMovesU Grants and Scholarships Program and wants to reward real-life Math Heroes for their dedication to improving math education. If you know someone who is an effective math teacher, math coach, or math event coordinator, nominate them as a Math Hero! Nominees must be full-time teachers who are currently employed and teaching a mathematics curriculum at a middle school or high school in the United States OR volunteers working with an approved math-related nonprofit organization (i.e. MATHCOUNTS®). Students, parents, colleagues, principals, or volunteers are eligible to nominate math teachers for the Math Hero Awards. Nominations will be based on the nominee’s enthusiasm and interest in improving math education. Finalists will be selected among nominees on the basis of testimonies about the effective and creative ways students are taught math. Finalists who are selected and notified by mail must complete a finalist application and indicate how they plan to use the grant to promote math education. Up to 3 awards of $2,500 each will be given to Math Hero recipients in each of the 9 target markets where Raytheon has a presence (AZ, CA, CO, FL, IN, MA, RI, TX, and VA). An additional 5 awards of $2,500 each will be granted to recipients outside of Raytheon’s target markets. A matching award of $2,500 will be granted to the school where each recipient is employed. The Math Hero will direct how the funds are used. The postmark deadline for nominations is May 16, 2012. For more information, please visit http://www.mathmovesu.com/#/home.

sec.title: USA Mathematical Talent Search
sec.p: The USA Mathematical Talent Search (USAMTS) is a free mathematics competition open to all United States middle and high school students. The goal of this competition is to help all students develop problem solving skills, improve their technical writing abilities, and mature mathematically. The competition exists to foster insight, ingenuity, and creativity in addition to perseverance, which is just as important in scientific endeavors. New problems are posted each month, and students must show all of their work and provide written justifications for each problem. The problems range in difficulty level. Students may use books, calculators, computers, but all the work must be their own. Student solutions to the USAMTS problems are graded by mathematicians and comments are returned to the students. Participants in the USAMTS are eligible for various prizes, such as books and software. Students who score well on the USAMTS are invited to take the American Invitational Mathematics Examination (AIME), which is the second step in the process of selecting the USA Mathematical Olympiad Team. With student permission, USAMTS participant’s names and addresses are provided to colleges, universities, and employers for recruitment purposes. For more information, please visit http://www.usamts.org/index.php.
